article.headline: West leads St. Joe's to 21st straight win
article.linkText: West leads St. Joe's to 21st straight win
article.story:
PHILADELPHIA (AP) _ Saint Joseph's ended the only losing streak
it has known lately.

	   Delonte West had 24 points and Jameer Nelson added 16 points and
seven assists to help the third-ranked Hawks remain undefeated with
an 81-67 victory over Dayton on Wednesday night.

	   Tyrone Barley was 3-for-4 from 3-point range and had 14 points
for the Hawks (21-0, 10-0 Atlantic 10) who snapped a three-game
streak against Dayton in extending their school-record winning
streak.
	   Saint Joseph's and No. 2 Stanford (20-0) remain the only
unbeaten teams in Division I. Rhode Island is the only team with a
winning record remaining on Saint Joseph's regular season schedule.
The Rams visit the Hawks on Saturday for the first of two meetings.

	   ``We've gotten a lot of notoriety in the Atlantic 10, but (the
Flyers) are the champions from last year,'' West said. ``They
flat-out beat us last year. I think we showed them something
today.''

	   With no loss from which to rebound this season, Saint Joseph's
turned back the calendar to last year when they were beaten twice
by the Flyers.

	   After Saturday's win over La Salle, Hawks coach Phil Martelli
wrote the scores of the Dayton victories on the locker room
blackboard.

	   The Hawks responded to their coach's challenge.
	   ``It's not about them. It's more about us,'' Martelli said. ``We
got beat by a better team last year. That idea of a loss lingers
with this team.''

	   The Flyers entered the game unbeaten in the conference and, with
a big, talented frontcourt, figured to be the biggest threat to
Saint Joseph's unbeaten record.

	   The matchup was also the first in A-10 history between teams
that were 9-0 in conference play.

	   None of the hype seemed to rattle the Hawks.
	   Saint Joseph's trailed 9-8 early, but not for the rest of the
game. Each time Dayton made a run, the Hawks answered with a timely
basket or clutch defensive play.

	   Forward John Bryant and center Dwayne Jones, overshadowed much
of the season by the Hawks' superior backcourt, helped shut down
the interior and hold Dayton to just seven assists.

	   ``When people say something negative about the frontcourt, I
take it personally because I'm in the frontcourt,'' said Jones, who
blocked three shots. ``My attitude every game is to shut people up.
Hopefully, I shut them up tonight.''

	   Dayton trailed by six points early in the second half before
Nelson made two free throws and a jumper to push the lead to 10.
After the Flyers' Ramod Marshall made a 19-footer, Pat Carroll
answered with a 3 that restored the lead to 11 points at halftime.

	   The lead would be trimmed to eight three more times, but it got
no smaller.

	   With 4:38 remaining, Nelson delivered a quick bounce pass in the
lane to West, who finished the play with a spectacular reverse
layup. West made a 3 on the next possession and another layup with
under 2 minutes to go that gave the Hawks their biggest lead of the
game.

	   The home crowd closed out the game with the now familiar chants
of ``Undefeated'' and ``The Hawk will never die.''

	   ``We wanted to make sure we defended our home court,'' Martelli
said.
	   It was a disappointing second half for Dayton, which got off to
a promising start.

	   The Flyers kept Saint Joseph's off-balance early and played
tough perimeter defense, holding the Hawks to a 1-for-7 start from
3-point range.

	   But Dayton also struggled early on the offensive end, hitting
just five of its first 19 field goal attempts.

	   Nelson was held scoreless until he stole a crosscourt pass and
took it the length of the floor for a layup that put Saint Joseph's
ahead by eight with 5:22 left in the first half. Nelson made a
running layup on the next possession and Carroll knocked down a 3
from the corner to extend the lead to 13.

	   Nelson had two 18-footers over the next 3 minutes to stave off a
Dayton run and give the Hawks the 36-25 halftime lead.

	   ``They're a veteran team with unbelievable court savvy because
of Nelson and West,'' Dayton coach Brian Gregory said. ``The
biggest reason for that is Nelson and West.''

	   Keith Waleskowski had 20 points and 10 rebounds for Dayton
(19-4, 9-1), which had won nine straight. Marshall added 16 points,
while Marques Bennett had a career-high 11.

	   Dayton had a 37-30 rebounding edge over the Hawks, but lost for
the first time all season when outrebounding its opponent.

	   Martelli received a technical foul midway through the second
half and was clearly frustrated with the officiating the rest of
the way.

	   ``That was the most unwarranted technical foul ever. I'll leave
it at that,'' Martelli said.
